case_name: Hindustan Hosiery Industries v. Mill Mazdoor Sabha

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 548 of 1970 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 548 of 1970. Appeal by Special Leave from the.

facts.text: Appeal against award dated 29th January 1970 of Industrial Court Maharashtra Bombay in reference IC No. 2 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the. Award dated the 29th January, 1970 of the Industrial Court, Maharashtra, Bombay, in reference  IC  No. 2 of 1969.

facts.text: Reference by Mill Mazdoor Sabha Bombay under section 73A of Bombay Industrial Relations Act 1946 pursuant to notice of change dated 22nd August 1968.

anchor.surface_text: There was a .reference by the Mill Mazdoor Sabha, Bombay  briefly the Sabha  under section 73A of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, 1946, in pursuance of a numberice of change dated 22nd August, 1968.

facts.text: Sabha demanded revised basic wages for time-rated workmen of several categories and 50 rise in wage of piece-rated workers in CPI bracket 621-636 old series.

anchor.surface_text: The Sabha demanded revised basic wages for the time-rated workmen of several categories and also a rise of 50 in the wage of the piece-rated workers in the Consumers Price Index bracket 621-636  old series .

facts.text: Sabha demanded dearness allowance of 10 paise per day for every rise of 10 points or part thereof above CPI 621-636 retrospectively from 1st June 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The Sabha also demanded dearness allowance of 10 paise per day for every rise of 10 points or part thereof above the said siab. They also claimed the benefits retrospectively from 1st June, 1968.

facts.text: Sabha submitted statement of claim on 14th February 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The Sabha submitted its statement of claim on 14th February, 1969.

facts.text: Appellant is partnership firm constituted and commenced production in April 1967 manufacturing nylon and hosiery goods registered as small scale industry.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the appellant is a partnership firm which was companystituted and companymenced production in April 1967. The firm manufactures and sells nylon and hosiery goods such as socks, undergarments, and the like.

facts.text: Prior to April 1967 partners of appellant were partners of Hindustan Hosiery Factory constituted 15th December 1963 after dissolution of India Hosiery Factory on 14th December 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to April 1967, all the partners of the appellant were partners of a firm known as M s. Hindustan Hosiery Factory. That firm again was companystituted and companymenced business on and from 15th December, 1963, after the dissolution of India Hosiery Factory on 14th December, 1963

facts.text: On 14th December 1963 some partners constituted Stretchlon Private Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date, some other partners of India Hosiery Factory companystituted another firm known as Stretchlon Private Ltd.

facts.text: Hindustan Hosiery Factory closed in August 1966; appellant commenced business as Hindustan Hosiery Industries on 17th April 1967; Hindustan Hosiery Mills also commenced same date.

anchor.surface_text: While Stretchlon Private Ltd. companytinued to function, Hindustan Hosiery Factory was closed in August 1966 and the appellant companystituted and companymenced business in the name- ,and style of Hindustan Hosiery Industries with effect from 17th April, 1967, on which date another firm also companymenced business under the name and style of Hindustan Hosiery Mills.

facts.text: All three firms Stretchlon Pvt Ltd, appellant, Hindustan Hosiery Mills are offshoots of India Hosiery Factory with complement of 800 workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that all these three firms, namely, Stretchlon Private Ltd., the appellant and the Hindustan Hosiery Mills are off shoots of the India Hosiery Factory with a companyplement of 800 workmen which was actually the pio- neer in the industry.

facts.text: Sabha contended time-rated workmen got Rs. 2.50 to 3.50 per day; piece-rated Rs. 6.1 to 7.1 per day.

anchor.surface_text: The Sabha companytended before the Tribunal that the companysolidated wages paid to the employees were extremely low. According to the Sabha, the time-rated workmen got as low a wage of Rs. 2.50 per day And never higher than Rs. 3.50 per day. The piece-rated workers,

facts.text: Appellant contended it is new concern employing some workers from Hindustan Hosiery Factory; piece-rated wages Rs. 6 to 10.20 per day adequate for highly skilled work; higher than other concerns; 250 workers; financial position not assessable as 2 years old.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant,, it is a new companycern and has employed some of the workers of the Hindustan Hosiery Factory. The average daily wages of the piece-rated jobs vary from Rs. 6/- to Rs. 10120 per day and are adequate. The work involved in the jobs is number of highly skilled nature.

facts.text: Tribunal observed from Ext C-2, C-3, books that many piece-rated and time-rated got Rs. 4.60 and Rs. 2.50 per day respectively; held wages inadequate even for loss-making concern.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had before it a statement  Ext. C-2  filed by the appellant showing the number of employees receiving wages below Rs. 5/- per day, another statement  Ext. C-3  with regard to the other employees and also the books filed by the appellant and observed that many of the piece-rated and time-rated employees got as low a wage as Rs. 4.60 per day and Rs. 2.50 per  fay respectively.

facts.text: Appellant started business on 17th April 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant started its business on 17th April, 1967.

facts.text: Appellant earned profits Rs. 1,51,000 in 8 months of 1967 and Rs. 1,88,000 in 1968 per Ext U-1; capital Rs. 2,28,000 in 1967, Rs. 3,42,000 in 1968; sound financial position.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal found from the statement, Ext. U-1, filed by the Sabha regarding its financial position that the appellant earned substantial profits in the period of 8 months In 1967 and in 1968. The Tribunal found that during the period of 20 months since April, 1967, the appellant has earned a profit of Rs.1,51,000/- in eight months of 1967 and Rs. 1,88,000/-- in 1968.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded Rs. 5 per day to first 13 lowest categories in CPI 621-630, Rs. 5.50 to 14-19, Rs.7 to 20-21, etc.; DA 10 paise per 10 points above; piece-rate +30; retrospective from 1st February 1969.

anchor.surface_text: Although the Sabha in this case has asked for different rates of basic wages for employees in five categories, the Tribunal directed that the first 13 categories being the lowest paid workers should receive Rs. 5/- per day in the Index bracket 621-630. The next group serial Nos. 14 to 19 were given Rs. 5.50 per day in the same bracket, serial Nos. 20-21 were given Rs. 7/- per day, serial No. 22 Rs. 7.50 per day and serial No. 23 Rs. 8.50 per day in the aforesaid bracket.

facts.text: Settlement between Hindustan Hosiery Mills and Sabha: increase Re.1 per day for workers getting Rs.5 or less, 50 paise for more; appellant prepared to allow, burden Rs.56,022 per year.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant also submitted that the Tribunal ought number to have ignored the settlement with regard to wage arrived at by the Hindustan Hosiery Mills with the Sabha. By that settlement, the said partnership firm companystituted by the other group of partners of Hindustan Hosiery factory agreed with the Sabha to give an increase of Re. 1/- per day ill the wages of the workers getting Rs. 5/- per day or less

facts.text: Sabha stated in written statement paras 5-6: wages excessively low, lower than minimum in Bombay region and comparables; concern can bear burden.

anchor.surface_text: In the written statement filed before the Court the Sabha stated in paragraphs 5 and 6 as follows The present wages of both the piece- rated and time rated workers are excessively low and are much lower than those companysidered to be the absolute minimum payable by any employer to his workers in the Bombay Region.

facts.text: Appellant in para 5 written statement: cannot bear additional burden; stability to be considered.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, in para 5 of their written statement before the Tribunal stated that it companyld number bear the additional burden which may arise on account of the revision of wages and D.A. as demanded by the first party

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal considered higher than bare minimum bordering fair wage based on Stretchlon award; appeal dismissed, no intervention.

anchor.surface_text: Taking a companyprehensive view of the facts and circumstances of the case, we are satisfied that numberintervention is called for with the award. In the result, the appeal is dismissed.

facts.text: Stretchlon Private Ltd award dated 10th April 1967 awarded Rs.5 per day minimum wage in CPI 621-630.

anchor.surface_text: produced an award of the Industrial Court in the case of Stretchlon Private Ltd. dated 10th April, 1967, published in the Maharashtra Gazette of 11th May, 1967. ... the Industrial Court, therefore, awarded Rs. 5/- per day as a reasonable and fair minimum wage to the Stretch on employees of the lowest category in the Consumers Price Index bracket 621-630.
